title: Ottawa Senators seem to relish time on the road Brennan | Hockey | Sports | To
text:
As much as they enjoyed being home for Thanksgiving dinner, there's no place like the road for the Ottawa Senators.
It is in their most recent games as the visitors, dating back to last season, that they've feasted on opponents.
Following Sunday's uninspired 3-1 loss to the Montreal Canadiens at Canadian Tire Centre, the Senators had a day off to sit back, eat some turkey, and cheer on the Toronto Blue Jays.
They'll be back at practice Tuesday morning and, after a celebration of life for the late Max Keeping, they'll head out for a two-stop trip that sees back-to-back games in Columbus and Pittsburgh. And while both the Blue Jackets and Penguins have started this season at 0-2, the Senators believe they are best served focusing mainly on their own game.
On the road, the game they play has produced positive results since Feb. 3, when they last failed to leave another team's building with at least a point on a run that has seen them compile a record of 13-0-3.
Back in the days before overtime, that would be 16 games without a defeat. The NHL record for one season is 23 games, set by the 1974-75 Habs who won 14 and tied nine.
"For the past 15 road games or so, obviously tying into last year, we've been pretty good," Senators defenceman Marc Methot said late Sunday night. "I think for us the biggest thing (on the road) is just making sure our legs are under us and we've got that jump, because the skill set is in the room. So I think over the next couple of games, we just have to take care of ourselves ... we're going to get a good practice in on Tuesday, and then I think (it's about) just sticking to our structure."
For whatever reason, the Senators didn't play hard enough against the Habs in Sunday's loss, a point made clear by coach Dave Cameron. They also didn't play at their best while squeaking out victories in Buffalo and Toronto to start this season.
But with a busy schedule out of the gate, they're not fretting over their standing.
"I think we should be happy, four out of six points," said captain Erik Karlsson. "If you would have said that before, we'd go three in four (nights) and get four points, we would have been happy with that. That's where we are right now, and we're satisfied with that."
Another stretch of three games in four nights begins Wednesday. Following the quick road trip, they'll have a one day break before hosting Nashville Saturday night.
Again, they hope to garner some momentum in the out-of-town tilts before trying to put on a better show for their fans against the Predators.
"We've felt pretty good on the road the last two," said Methot, adding that he was only made aware of the 13-0-3 run while reading Twitter on the weekend. "Buffalo and Toronto was a little back and forth, but I mean we're starting the season playing three (games) in four (nights) and that's not an easy thing to do. That's not easy in February, let alone your first three games.
"One good thing, you get them out of the way, especially if you can pot a couple of wins. Managing your body and fatigue is something you've got to get accustomed to again. It's not the summer where you're going to bed at 9:30 anymore at night, or 10:30 and you're on your couch melting. It's being primed and ready to play, and I think that will come.
"Now that we've got a bunch of games under our belt, we're going to feel better and better. Guys are going to get their hands back, their legs back. That takes times."
The Senators will also get Craig Anderson back between the pipes, at least for the Columbus game but quite likely Thursday in Pittsburgh too. Rookie backup Matt O'Connor played well enough against the Habs Sunday, aside from giving up a weak first goal, but that one mistake should remind them they need to go with their best in all-important inter-conference games.
Especially when they're played on the road.
Brennan
